qas.question: Precipitation hardening alloys produce the opposite effects of?
Precipitation hardening alloys are sometimes also?
What makes alloys more softer than normal?

answers.text: When heated to form a solution and then cooled quickly

qas.question: What do precipitation hardening alloys behave similarly to?
What alloys become softer when cooled slowly?
What type of alloys become soft and brittle?
What are easy to discern from the base metal?

context: Conversely, most <a1_0><b4_0>heat-treatable alloys<b4_0/><a1_0/> are <b5_0>precipitation hardening alloys<b5_0/>, which produce the opposite effects that <a0_0><b3_0>steel<b3_0/><a0_0/> does. <a2_0>When heated to form a solution and then cooled quickly<a2_0/>, these alloys become much softer than normal, during the diffusionless transformation, and then harden as they age. The solutes in these alloys will precipitate over time, forming <b7_0>intermetallic phases<b7_0/>, which are difficult to discern from the base metal. Unlike steel, in which the solid solution separates to form different crystal phases, precipitation hardening alloys separate to form different phases within the same crystal. These <b6_0>intermetallic alloys<b6_0/> appear homogeneous in crystal structure, but tend to behave heterogeneous, becoming hard and somewhat brittle.
